questions.text: Which of the following is correct about function of utricle and saccule? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Linear acceleration

 

The utricle and saccule are part of the vestibular system in the inner ear, which is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and orientation. They do not participate in the hearing process but are involved in sensing linear accelerations.

 

  • Utricle: Senses horizontal linear movements.
  • Saccule: Senses vertical linear movements.

 

Both structures contain sensory epithelia known as the maculae, which house hair cells that respond to shifts in movement through the displacement of tiny stones called otoliths on a gel-like layer.

 

Semicircular canals sense the Angular movements.

 

Hearing is sensed by Organ of Corti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hearing high frequency sounds & C. Hearing low frequency sounds: These functions are attributed to the cochlea, where sound vibrations are converted into nerve signals that are interpreted by the brain. High and low frequency sound detection is facilitated by different regions of the cochlear basilar membrane.

 

Option D. Angular acceleration: This is the specific function of the semicircular canals, which are filled with fluid and contain sensory hair cells that respond to the rotation of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The utricle and saccule are essential for detecting linear movements, helping the body maintain balance and posture in response to everyday activities and motion, while the cochlea and semicircular canals perform separate functions related to hearing and angular motion detection, respectively.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes with excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge from the ear and HbA1c of 10. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Necrotizing otitis externa

 

Given the description of excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge, and the presence of uncontrolled diabetes (indicated by the high HbA1c level), the most likely diagnosis is Necrotizing otitis externa. This condition is a serious, potentially life-threatening infection that requires immediate medical attention.

 

Necrotizing otitis externa is a severe form of otitis externa that occurs primarily in diabetic patients or those who are immunocompromised. It is characterized by infection that extends into the bone and cartilage of the ear canal, causing severe pain, otorrhea (often bloody), and potentially serious complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa, commonly known as "swimmer's ear," is an inflammation of the ear canal that can cause ear pain and discharge. While it can be painful, it typically does not cause the severe symptoms seen in diabetic patients with poorly controlled blood sugar levels.

 

Option C. Serous otitis media involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It typically causes a feeling of fullness in the ear and decreased hearing but is not typically associated with severe pain or bloody discharge.

 

Option D. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, which can present with ear pain, fever, and hearing loss. In severe cases, it may lead to tympanic membrane rupture, which can cause bloody discharge. However, the pain is not usually described as excruciating and does not typically have the same level of severity as necrotizing otitis externa in a diabetic patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with excruciating ear pain and bloody otorrhea, the diagnosis of necrotizing otitis externa should be considered, especially when the patient has a significantly elevated HbA1c, indicating poor glycemic control.

choices.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. On examination, following was seen on the CECT. All are false except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumor vessel lack contractility

 

Based on the provided CT image and the clinical context of recurrent bleeding, the most accurate statement is Tumor vessels lack contractility, which contributes to the propensity for bleeding in tumorous growths.

 

"Tumor vessel lack contractility" is a true statement about tumor vessels. They are often abnormally formed, with poor structural integrity and can lack the ability to contract, which normally helps control bleeding when vessels are injured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outgrown the blood supply: Suggests that the lesion has grown faster than the blood vessels can proliferate to support it. This can lead to areas of necrosis within tumours.

 

Option C. Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels: Implies that the normal vessels adjacent to the tumor are the source of bleeding. However, the bleeding associated with tumors is usually due to the tumor vessels themselves because they are prone to rupture, not the adjacent normal vessels.

 

Option D. Lacks capsule: May or may not be true depending on the type of tumor. Some benign tumors have a well-defined capsule, while malignant tumors often lack a capsule. However, this option does not directly relate to the issue of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor vessels are known to lack contractility, which contributes to the risk of bleeding associated with tumors, as they cannot constrict effectively to stop blood flow when damaged.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles on the tympanic membrane and in the external auditory meatus, accompanied by features of facial nerve palsy. What is the diagnosis and which site is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

 

Clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay hunt syndrome (aka herpes zoster oticus).

 

Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay–Hunt Syndrome) - It is a viral infection (herpes zoster virus) involving geniculate ganglion of facial nerve. It is characterized by appearance of vesicles on the tympanic membrane, deep meatus, concha and retro auricular sulcus.

 

It appears as a rash of small tense blisters with surrounding erythema, preceded by pain in the ears for several days

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome and Basal Ganglion: Incorrect because Ramsay Hunt syndrome affects the geniculate ganglion, not the basal ganglion.

 

Option C. & D. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by a triad of recurrent facial nerve paralysis, swelling of the lips (cheilitis granulomatosa), and a fissured tongue. It does not involve vesicular eruptions and primarily affects the facial appearance and function without vesicular rash. Paralysis may be recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a reactivation of herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a characteristic vesicular eruption on the ear and facial nerve palsy. Early recognition and treatment are vital to prevent complications and improve recovery.

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: In the presence of tracheal deviation as indicated on a chest X-ray, which procedure is the most difficult to perform? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

A tracheostomy involves creating an opening through the neck into the trachea, which may become complicated when the trachea is deviated. In cases of tracheal deviation, the trachea is not in its usual midline position, which can make locating the correct spot for incision more challenging. This difficulty is increased because the trachea's position may not be easily palpable or visible due to its displacement, which can complicate the procedure and increase the risk of complications.

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal airway: A laryngeal airway (LMA) is inserted above the larynx at the supraglottic level. Since this procedure does not involve the trachea directly, a deviated trachea does not affect the placement of an LMA, making it relatively easy to perform.

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation may become slightly more difficult with tracheal deviation, it usually remains manageable. The main challenge might be encountering some resistance or needing to adjust the angle of the tube. However, with careful maneuvering, the endotracheal tube can still be guided into the trachea.

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy: This procedure involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane, located above the trachea at the level of the larynx. Because the tracheal deviation occurs below this point, it does not directly impact the cricothyroidotomy, making it a viable option even with tracheal deviation.

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy can be more challenging in cases of tracheal deviation due to the altered position of the trachea, making the precise location for incision difficult to identify.

questions.text: A female presents with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Rinne’s test reveals conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, a red and bulgy mass behind the intact tympanic membrane is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glomus tumor

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of glomus tumor

 

Glomus tumor

 

It is the most common benign neoplasm of middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

 

The tumor consists of paraganglionic cells derived from the neural crest.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Typically presents with an effusion in the middle ear without signs of infection, leading to a dull or amber appearance of the tympanic membrane rather than a red mass.

 

Option C. Chronic otitis media: Characterized by persistent ear infections and can include a perforated tympanic membrane or cholesteatoma, not typically presenting as a red mass.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Affects the ossicles, particularly the stapes, and leads to conductive hearing loss. It does not present as a visible mass in the ear canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a red, pulsatile mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a patient with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss is highly suggestive of a glomus tympanicum tumor, requiring detailed imaging for confirmation and planning of appropriate intervention strategies.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Montgomery T tube

 

Montgomery T tube is a type of silicone stent used in the management of tracheal and subglottic stenosis. It is T-shaped to allow it to fit snugly in the trachea with one limb exiting the stoma, allowing for breathing through the upper airway or the tube itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a device inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to facilitate speech in patients who have had a total laryngectomy

 

Option C. Blom-Singer prosthesis is a type of tracheoesophageal puncture voice prosthesis used for voice rehabilitation after a laryngectomy. When a patient has their larynx removed, typically due to cancer, they lose their natural voice. A Blom-Singer prosthesis is a one-way valve inserted between the trachea and the esophagus that allows air to be diverted into the esophagus to produce sound, enabling the patient to speak. It is placed during surgery or as an office procedure after the surgical site has healed.

 

Option D. A Grommet, also known as a tympanostomy tube or ventilation tube, is a small tube inserted into the eardrum to allow air to enter the middle ear. It is used to treat recurrent middle ear infections (acute otitis media) or to relieve chronic fluid accumulation in the middle ear (otitis media with effusion). Grommets help reduce the frequency of ear infections and improve hearing by allowing the continuous drainage of fluid and equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the external atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher presents with difficulty hearing lower frequencies, particularly male voices. On examination, the apex of the cochlea shows degenerative changes. Which of the following structures lies nearest to the affected region? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: A) Helicotrema

 

Explanation: 

 

The affected structure in low-frequency hearing loss is the apical turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies nearest to this region is the helicotrema.

According to von Bekesy's traveling wave theory:

  • Sound waves create a traveling wave along the basilar membrane
  • Different frequencies resonate at specific locations
  • Lower frequencies are processed at the apex of the cochlea
  • The helicotrema, located at the apex, connects scala vestibuli and scala tympani
  • This region is crucial for low-frequency sound processing

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oval Window: Located near the base of the cochlea, it's associated with high-frequency sound processing, not low-frequency hearing.

 

Option C. Round Window: Also located at the basal end of the cochlea, it's anatomically distant from the apex where low-frequency sounds are processed.

 

Option D. Modiolus: While it runs through the center of the cochlea, it's not specifically closest to the apical region where low-frequency sounds are processed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the tonotopic organization of the cochlea is crucial for localizing hearing deficits. Low-frequency sounds are processed in the apex near the helicotrema, while high-frequency sounds are processed at the base near the oval and round windows.

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction after being hit on the face from the front. On examination, a boggy swelling of the septum is seen on both sides (see picture below), which is fluctuant on palpation with a swab or blunt probe. He should be managed by?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incision & Drainage

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with nasal obstruction and a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum on both sides after trauma, which indicates a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septal tissues and requires immediate drainage to prevent complications such as infection, abscess formation, or septal cartilage necrosis. The definitive treatment is incision and drainage to evacuate the collected blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal packing: Nasal packing is not the treatment of choice for a septal hematoma. It is typically used for controlling nasal bleeding (epistaxis).

 

Option C. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infection, they do not address the primary issue of the hematoma and are not the definitive treatment.

 

Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants are used to reduce nasal mucosal swelling and congestion but are not effective in treating a septal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A septal hematoma, characterized by a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum after nasal trauma, should be treated with immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scala tympani

 

The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the Scala tympani.

 

A cochlear implant works by producing meaningful electrical stimulation of the auditory nerve where degeneration of the hair cells in the cochlea has progressed to a point such that amplification provided by hearing aids is no longer effective.

 

The principle of cochlear implant surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. This allows the electrodes to be in close proximity to the spiral ganglion cells and their dendrites (that lie in the modiolus and osseous spiral lamina of the cochlea, respectively).

 

There are broadly two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation:

 

  1. The facial recess approach where a simple cortical mastoidectomy is done. The facial recess is opened by performing a posterior tympanotomy. The stapes, promontory and round window niche are identified. Cochleostomy is then performed anteroinferior to the round window membrane to a diameter of 1.0 - 1.6 mm depending on the electrode to be used.
  2. The pericanal techniques where a tympanomeatal flap is elevated to perform a cochleostomy either by endaural or postaural approach. In the pericanal techniques a bony tunnel is drilled along the external canal towards the middle ear. The examples of pericanal techniques include the Veria and suprameatal recess approach.

 

The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Round window - Not typically the site for electrode placement in cochlear implants.

 

Option B. Oval window - Also not used for electrode placement; this structure connects the middle ear to the inner ear.

 

Option C. Scala vestibuli - Another perilymph-filled cavity in the cochlea, but not the preferred location for electrode placement due to its anatomy and relation to the auditory pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal auditory nerve stimulation, highlighting the importance of precision in surgical approaches to maximize the benefits of the implant.

choices.text: Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches

questions.text: A patient presents with repeated infections from the lesion shown in the image. The correct statement in relation to the image is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Derived from 1st and 2nd arches

 

Given the location of the lesion near the ear and the recurrent infections which are characteristic of a preauricular sinus, the correct statement is Option C. Derived from 1st and 2nd arches.

 

These lesions are ectodermal in origin and are related to the developmental defects of the first and second branchial arches, which also contribute to the formation of the auricle (external ear).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Derived from first cleft" refers to structures that develop from the first branchial cleft in embryonic development. External ear structures, such as the external auditory canal, are derived from the first cleft, but preauricular sinuses are not typically included in this category.

 

Option B. "Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches" refers to internal structures of the ear that can be affected by branchial pouch anomalies. However, preauricular sinuses are not associated with the internal structures derived from the pouches.

 

Option D. "Derived from 3rd and 4th arches" is incorrect for preauricular lesions. The third and fourth branchial arches contribute to the development of parts of the hyoid bone and the structures of the neck, not the external ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses or cysts are congenital lesions derived from the first and second branchial arches and are associated with the external ear, often presenting with recurrent infections

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with hearing loss. On examination, a white pearly mass is seen behind an intact TM as shown below. There is no history of TM perforation or surgery. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital cholesteatoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The presence of a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a young child with no history of tympanic membrane perforation or surgery strongly suggests congenital cholesteatoma. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs due to the presence of residual epithelial cells trapped within the middle ear during embryogenesis, which later proliferate. This condition is typically seen in the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary cholesteatoma: Primary cholesteatoma usually involves a retraction pocket and is associated with a history of eustachian tube dysfunction. It is not typically seen with an intact tympanic membrane without a history of perforation or retraction.

 

Option C. Secondary cholesteatoma: Secondary cholesteatoma arises due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with tympanic membrane perforation or from a previous surgical procedure. It does not present with an intact tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Tubotympanic CSOM: Tubotympanic chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is associated with a central perforation of the tympanic membrane and chronic discharge. It is not consistent with an intact tympanic membrane and a white pearly mass.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in the absence of any history of perforation or surgery. It is typically found in the anterosuperior quadrant of the middle ear.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

 

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS

 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)
  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.
  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas
  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.
  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness
  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)
  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Although previously considered a fungus, current classifications based on molecular analysis place Rhinosporidium seeberi under protozoa.

 

Option B: Viruses are infectious agents that replicate inside the living cells of organisms which is not a characteristic of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Option D: Bacteria are single-celled microorganisms with simple internal structures, quite distinct from the complex life cycle and morphology of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. The CT scan results are depicted in the image provided. What might be the potential underlying reason for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted Papilloma

 

An elderly patient with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis and a mass visible points to a diagnosis of Inverted Papilloma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maxillary carcinoma arises from maxillary sinus lining and presents with facial paresthesia, lacrimation and pain.

 

 

Option C. Esthesioneuroblastoma/ Olfactory neuroblastomas are tumors arising from the basal layer of the olfactory epithelium in the superior recess of the nasal cavity. They usually present as a soft tissue mass in the superior olfactory recess involving the anterior and middle ethmoid air-cells on one side and extending through the cribriform plate into the anterior cranial fossa.

 

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is seen exclusively in males. Commonly presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted Papilloma should be considered when an elderly patient presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and imaging reveals a mass, especially when the presentation includes epistaxis and nasal obstruction without the severe pain or neurological symptoms that might suggest a more malignant etiology.

questions.text: A surgeon is planning to use topical Mitomycin-C (10mg) in a post-surgical case. Which of the following conditions would most appropriately benefit from its application? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pterygium surgery

 

Explanation: 

 

Mitomycin-C is appropriate for pterygium surgery because:

  • It acts as an antifibrotic agent that prevents post-surgical scarring and recurrence
  • The antiproliferative properties help prevent fibrovascular regrowth
  • Topical application during pterygium surgery significantly reduces recurrence rates
  • Standard concentration of 0.02% (0.2 mg/ml) is used intraoperatively for 2-3 minutes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis: Requires systemic antifungal medications; Mitomycin-C has no role 

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy: A straightforward surgical removal procedure where antifibrotic agents are not indicated 

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty: While it involves tissue repair, Mitomycin-C is not routinely used due to risks of ototoxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mitomycin-C has dual applications: antineoplastic (systemic use) and antifibrotic (topical use)
  • Key applications in surgery focus on preventing post-surgical scarring and fibrosis
  • Major ophthalmic applications include pterygium surgery and glaucoma filtering procedures
  • Careful dosing and application time are crucial to prevent complications
  • The drug's effectiveness is based on its ability to inhibit DNA synthesis and fibroblast proliferation

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to ENT OPD with severe dysphagia of recent onset and muffled voice. On examination, a cherry red swollen epiglottis was seen behind the tongue. On X-ray, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The child presents with severe dysphagia, a muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis, which are classic signs of acute epiglottitis. The X-ray shows the characteristic "thumb sign," indicating a swollen epiglottis. Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention. The child will typically sit in the tripod position to help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Also known as croup, this condition typically presents with a barking cough and stridor. The X-ray shows the "steeple sign," which is not seen here.

 

Option C. Acute laryngitis: Acute laryngitis involves inflammation of the vocal cords, leading to hoarseness, but does not typically cause severe dysphagia or a swollen epiglottis.

 

Option D. Syphilis larynx: Syphilis affecting the larynx is rare and presents with different symptoms, such as hoarseness or a sore throat, rather than an acute swollen epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute epiglottitis presents with severe dysphagia, muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis. The "thumb sign" on X-ray is a characteristic finding, and immediate medical intervention is necessary.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and found to have Rinne's negative at 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz, with Weber test lateralizing to the affected ear. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45-60 dB

 

Explanation: 

 

In this case, the clinical findings suggest a more severe conductive hearing loss because:

  • Rinne's test is negative at all frequencies (256Hz, 512Hz, and 1024Hz), indicating a significant air-bone gap
  • When Rinne's test is negative for all three frequencies (256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz), it indicates an approximate hearing loss of 45-60dB
  • Weber test lateralizing to the affected ear confirms conductive hearing loss
  • This pattern suggests a more severe conductive component compared to the original question where Rinne was positive at 1024 Hz

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30-45 dB: This gap would show Rinne positive at 1024 Hz 

 

Option B. 15-30 dB: This smaller gap would show Rinne positive at both 512 Hz and 1024 Hz 

 

Option D.  >60 dB: Such severe losses are uncommon in typical conductive hearing loss and would likely have additional clinical findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuning fork test interpretation is frequency-dependent - the more frequencies showing negative Rinne, the larger the air-bone gap
  • Sequential pattern to remember for conductive hearing loss severity: 
    • Negative at 256 Hz only → ~15-20 dB gap
    • Negative at 256 Hz & 512 Hz → ~30-45 dB gap
    • Negative at all frequencies (256, 512, 1024 Hz) → ~45-60 dB gap
  • Weber test always lateralizes to the affected ear in conductive hearing loss, regardless of severity
  • A comprehensive assessment should include multiple frequencies as testing at a single frequency can miss milder losses or underestimate severity

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

 

The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

 

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is viral in origin and is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 and 11.
  • It is presumed that affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus disease.
  • Papilloma’s mostly affect supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea and bronchi. DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Patients, often a child, between the age of 3 and 5 years present with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change.
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament. Other modalities of tumor removal are with cold steel instruments or  debrider or coblation or radiofrequency. Aim of therapy is to maintain a good airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
  • Adjuvant medical therapies include Interferon alpha-2a and 13-cis-retinoic acid has been used.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Reinke's edema - Characterized by swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, not similar to the warty growths of papillomas.

 

Option B. Malignancy - Would typically appear more irregular and could involve more invasive growth patterns.

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia - A condition related to the softening of the tracheal walls, not relevant to laryngeal lesions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 345

questions.text: A teacher presents with the following condition and hoarseness of the voice. Identify.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule

 

Based on the description of the condition causing hoarseness in a teacher, a profession associated with voice strain, the most likely diagnosis is Vocal nodule.

 

Vocal nodules are bilateral, benign growths that typically occur at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. They are often a result of vocal strain or overuse and present with a hoarse voice. The nodules are usually symmetrical and look like small bumps on either side of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal carcinoma usually presents as an irregular, often unilateral growth on the vocal cord, and it can cause hoarseness. The lesion may have an irregular surface and can vary in coloration from the surrounding tissue. It is typically associated with risk factors like smoking and alcohol use.

 

Option C. Reinke’s edema is characterized by the swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke's space (the layer of the vocal cord). The cords appear swollen and may take on a polypoid appearance, often associated with a lower-pitched, hoarse voice. Smoking is a common risk factor.

 

Option D. Vocal polyps are usually unilateral and can vary in size. They are often the result of acute vocal trauma or misuse. Polyps can cause hoarseness and have a soft, fluid-filled appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are benign, symmetrical lesions typically located at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords, often resulting from chronic vocal strain, and present with symptoms of hoarseness.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battle sign

 

The image shows Battle's sign.

 

It is retroarticular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

 

Option D: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition

questions.text: A 3-year-old was brought to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing since 2 hours. A radiograph was done as shown below. What will be the next step to manage the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Esophagoscopy

 

A round metallic foreign body lies in the midline just above the aortic knob, suggestive of a foreign body within the esophagus, the coin exceeds the diameter of the trachea. Also, both lung fields appear clear.  

 

A PA and lateral view X-ray of chest and abdomen should be done.

 

Treatment – Removal of foreign body by esophagoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchoscopy: Used if there is suspicion that the foreign body might have entered the respiratory tract. In this scenario, the foreign body is in the esophagus, not the trachea.

 

Option B. Tracheostomy: Not appropriate in this case as there is no indication of airway compromise that cannot be managed by less invasive means.

 

Option D. Heimlich’s Maneuver: This is used for choking due to an airway obstruction, not for foreign bodies lodged in the esophagus. It's inappropriate and could potentially cause harm by forcing the object into a more problematic position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected esophageal foreign bodies in children, esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both confirmation and removal of the object. It ensures that the foreign body is safely and effectively retrieved while minimizing risk to the patient.

choices.text: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngomalacia? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Most common in newborn

 

Laryngomalacia is indeed most common in newborns and is often noticed shortly after birth. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia typically presents with inspiratory stridor, not expiratory. This stridor is due to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inhalation.

 

Option B. The stridor of laryngomalacia typically worsens in the supine position. This is because the supraglottic structures are more likely to collapse into the airway when a child is lying on their back.

 

Option D. Most children with laryngomalacia do not require surgical management. The condition is often self-limiting and tends to improve as the child grows and the laryngeal structures become more rigid, usually by 18 to 24 months of age. Surgery is reserved for severe cases where there are feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, severe stridor, or apnea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that typically worsens in the supine position and is most commonly diagnosed in newborns. The condition generally resolves on its own without the need for surgical intervention in most cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of the tracheostomy tube shown in the image? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fenestration window

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows standard PVC tracheostomy tubes without fenestrations. Fenestrated tubes have a window or opening in the outer cannula to allow airflow through the larynx for phonation, which is not visible in these tubes. The tubes shown are:

  • Made of thermosensitive PVC (becomes softer at body temperature)
  • Have different colored caps indicating sizes
  • Compatible with inner cannula (for cleaning)
  • Suitable for prolonged mechanical ventilation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Thermosensitive material - These are clearly PVC tubes which are thermosensitive, becoming softer at body temperature for patient comfort.

 

Option C: Inner cannula - These tubes are compatible with inner cannulas, which can be removed for cleaning while maintaining airway patency.

 

Option D: Prolonged mechanical ventilation compatibility - Standard PVC tracheostomy tubes are designed for long-term ventilation with appropriate connectors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand:

  1. Different types of tracheostomy tubes and their features
  2. Clinical applications of various tube designs
  3. Material properties of modern tracheostomy tubes
  4. Importance of tube selection based on patient needs
  5. Recognition of specific features like fenestration vs non-fenestration

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with unilateral hearing loss and fullness in the ear. Nasopharyngeal endoscopy shows the finding in the image. Which structure's pathology is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Opening of eustachian tube

 

Explanation: 

 

The endoscopic image shows the lateral wall of nasopharynx. The patient's symptoms of unilateral hearing loss and ear fullness strongly suggest eustachian tube dysfunction. The eustachian tube opening is located at the torus tubarius on the lateral nasopharyngeal wall. Obstruction or dysfunction of this opening leads to negative middle ear pressure and conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fossa of Rosenmuller: While this is the depression posterior to the torus tubarius and is a critical anatomical landmark (being the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma), isolated pathology here wouldn't typically cause eustachian tube symptoms without adjacent involvement.

 

Option B. Tubal tonsil: Although hypertrophy can contribute to eustachian tube dysfunction, isolated tubal tonsil pathology is less common than primary eustachian tube opening problems.

 

Option D. Adenoid: Located on the posterior nasopharyngeal wall, not the lateral wall shown in the image. While adenoid hypertrophy can cause eustachian tube dysfunction, it typically presents bilaterally and is more common in children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand:

  1. Anatomical relationships in the lateral nasopharyngeal wall
  2. Clinical correlation of eustachian tube dysfunction
  3. Differential diagnosis of unilateral hearing loss
  4. Importance of nasopharyngeal endoscopy in ear symptoms
  5. Recognition of normal nasopharyngeal landmarks

questions.text: A child as shown below presented to the ENT department with the following finding. She gives complaint of recurrent bony fractures along with reduced hearing. On further investigation, Tympanometry showed the following finding. What would you name this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Van der Hoeve syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta (imperfectly developed bones).

 

The tympanometry shows an AS type of curve, suggesting otosclerosis.

 

Additionally, the child has a blue sclera, which is a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

This combination of symptoms — osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis — forms a triad known as Van der Hoeve syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waardenburg syndrome: Waardenburg syndrome is characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and pigmentary abnormalities such as a white forelock of hair (piebaldism).

 

 

Option C. Usher's syndrome: Usher's syndrome is associated with retinitis pigmentosa and congenital sensorineural hearing loss.

 

                Retinitis pigmentosa

 

Option D. Pendred syndrome: Pendred syndrome includes congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van der Hoeve syndrome is characterized by the triad of osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis.

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

 

  • Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

 

 

  • Jarjaway fracture - Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

 

 

Tripod fracture – is zygomatic fracture. Zygoma is separated into three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Citelli fracture - This does not pertain to the nasal septum but rather involves other cranial structures.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture - This is a zygomatic fracture where the zygoma is separated into three processes. The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture, unrelated to the nasal septum fractures.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: A teacher presented with complaints of hoarseness of voice. On examination, bilateral swelling was noted on anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vocal nodule 

 

Clinical history suggests a most probable diagnosis of vocal nodule

 

Vocal Nodules (aka Singer's nodule/Teacher's nodule)

 

Pathogenesis – Trauma → submucosal oedema & hemorrhage → hyalinization & fibrosis

 

Site: appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cord, at junction of anterior 1/3rd & posterior 2/3rd of vocal cord (Bilateral) as this is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus subject to maximum trauma

 

Clinical feature – Hoarseness, Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation are other common symptoms.

 

Treatment - Voice rest, Speech therapy, Micro laryngeal surgery if persistent

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal Polyp is an exophytic lesion with thin mucosa, caused by sudden shouting. Presents with Hoarseness of voice, Diplophonia (double voice).

 

 

Option C. Vocal Cyst are retention cysts occur in false vocal cords.

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema is Diffuse collection of oedema fluid in sub-epithelial space, MC in smokers. On examination, saddle-bag appearance of vocal cords on laryngoscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are common in individuals who frequently use their voices intensely, and they require a combination of vocal rest, speech therapy, and possibly surgical intervention to manage effectively and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Water’s view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen – 

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application – Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen –

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: Identify the condition based on this image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

The image shows a chest X-ray with dextrocardia, a condition where the heart is positioned on the right side of the chest. This is a key feature of situs inversus, which is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome.

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by a triad of clinical features: recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. The presence of situs inversus, as indicated by dextrocardia on the X-ray, is a distinguishing feature that confirms the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, characterized by thick, sticky mucus that can clog the airways and lead to infections. It does not typically present with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Young syndrome also involves recurrent sinusitis and bronchiectasis, similar to Kartagener syndrome. However, it is distinguished by infertility due to azoospermia rather than situs inversus. The absence of dextrocardia or situs inversus on imaging excludes Young syndrome as the correct answer.

 

Option D. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal inflammation leading to crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal block, and enlarged nasal cavities. It does not involve bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, or situs inversus, making it unrelated to the features seen in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Kartagener syndrome is identified by the presence of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (including dextrocardia), which is clearly visible in the chest X-ray provided.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with progressive unilateral nasal obstruction for 6 months and occasional clear rhinorrhea. Transnasal endoscopic findings are shown in the image. CT scan shows a soft tissue mass extending from maxillary sinus through accessory ostium into the nasal cavity and choana. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antrochoanal polyp

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation and imaging findings are characteristic of antrochoanal polyp. Key points supporting this diagnosis:

  • Female patient (unlike JNA which occurs in adolescent males)
  • Unilateral presentation
  • No history of epistaxis
  • Clear rhinorrhea rather than bleeding
  • CT showing origin from maxillary sinus with typical extension pattern
  • Endoscopic appearance showing smooth, pale mass

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Typically occurs in adolescent males, presents with epistaxis, and shows intense contrast enhancement on CT. The patient's gender and lack of bleeding make this unlikely.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: Presents with crusty discharge, tends to be bilateral, and shows characteristic histological features. CT would show more inflammatory changes.

 

Option D. Concha bullosa: This is pneumatization of the middle turbinate, appears as an air-filled cavity on CT, and doesn't present as a mass extending into the choana.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand:

  1. Differential diagnosis of unilateral nasal masses
  2. Role of patient demographics in diagnosis
  3. Characteristic imaging patterns of different nasal pathologies
  4. Importance of endoscopic appearance in diagnosis
  5. Natural history and extension patterns of sinonasal polyps

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

The given clinical scenario, image showing a patient with polypoidal mass and HPE image revealing sporangium, points to a diagnosis of Rhinosporidiosis.

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)

  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.

  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas

  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.

  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness

  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)

  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

Other Options:

Option A. Nasal polyp: Typically presents as a non-neoplastic mass, usually bilateral and associated with conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis. They do not bleed on touch and do not have the characteristic histopathological findings seen in Rhinosporidiosis.

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumors that appear as reddish-blue lesions, which are compressible and usually do not present with the same histopathological features as Rhinosporidiosis.

Option D. Rhinophyma: A severe form of rosacea resulting in a large, bulbous, and red nose. It is not associated with nasal bleeding or the histopathological findings presented in this case.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

The given clinical scenario and the image findings are suggestive of a frontal mucocele.

 

A frontal mucocele is a benign cystic lesion that develops in the frontal sinus, which is one of the air-filled spaces located in the forehead region of the skull. It typically occurs as a result of the blockage or obstruction of the frontal sinus drainage pathway, leading to the accumulation of mucus within the sinus cavity. Over time, the trapped mucus can cause the sinus walls to expand, forming a mucocele.

 

 

Patient presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningiomas: originates from the meninges, benign brain tumors presenting with headaches, seizures, vomiting, personality changes, and cognitive impairment. Given below is a Coronal MRI section.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: is the most common benign tumor of nasopharynx. Patients present with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of the orbit: is an idiopathic inflammation of the orbit presenting with painful proptosis, diplopia, and orbital congestion. Imaging shows right medial rectus muscle which is diffusely enlarged with moderate homogeneous enhancement with relative involvement of its tendinous insertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient developed severe respiratory distress within 6 hours postoperatively, with tense and painful anterior neck swelling. Repeated attempts at neck extension worsen the symptoms. The most probable cause is: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical scenario suggests post-thyroidectomy hematoma because:

  • Early onset (within 6-8 hours) of respiratory distress is typical
  • Tense, painful neck swelling is characteristic
  • Worsening with neck extension is a classic sign
  • Immediate surgical evacuation is required to prevent airway compromise

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury: Causes voice changes and aspiration but not acute neck swelling 

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Results in hoarseness but not acute respiratory distress 

 

Option C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Presents with immediate post-operative extubation difficulty rather than progressive respiratory distress

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hematoma is a surgical emergency requiring immediate evacuation
  • Key distinguishing features include: 
    • Early onset (usually within 6-8 hours)
    • Progressive neck swelling
    • Pain and tension in neck
    • Worsening with neck extension
  • Time is critical - delay in recognition can lead to airway compromise
  • Prevention includes meticulous hemostasis and close post-operative monitoring
  • All post-thyroidectomy patients with respiratory symptoms need immediate evaluation to rule out hematoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old female took aspirin for headache and she developed wheezing and breathlessness. This will be associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nasal Polyp

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of a condition known as Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), commonly known as Samter’s triad. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • Asthma
  • Nasal polyposis (particularly ethmoidal polyps)
  • Sensitivity to aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)

 

When individuals with this triad ingest aspirin, they can experience severe respiratory reactions including nasal congestion, asthma attacks, and even anaphylaxis. This reaction is not mediated by IgE, which is the common pathway for allergic reactions, but through alterations in leukotriene and prostaglandin metabolism.

 

Details on Nasal Polyps:

 

  • Nasal polyps are benign growths that occur in the lining of the nasal passages or sinuses.
  • They are associated with chronic inflammation and are often seen in conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased IgE: While increased IgE is typical of allergic reactions (allergic asthma, allergic rhinitis), AERD is a non-IgE mediated reaction.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Also known as allergic asthma, it involves an IgE-mediated response to external allergens, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Drug interaction: While the symptoms can be perceived as a drug interaction, they are actually a specific pharmacological reaction to NSAIDs in patients with AERD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the link between aspirin ingestion and respiratory symptoms in patients with nasal polyps is crucial for managing their condition effectively. Patients diagnosed with AERD should avoid NSAIDs and may need specific treatments for asthma and nasal polyps, along with alternatives to NSAIDs for pain management.

 

Samter’s triad: Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity

questions.text: What type of stridor occur in croup?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biphasic stridor

 

Given the question is about croup, the correct answer is Biphasic stridor, because croup usually affects the subglottic region and can cause narrowing that affects both phases of breathing.

 

Biphasic stridor is heard during both inhalation and exhalation and indicates a narrowing at the level of the vocal cords or just below them in the subglottic region. This type of stridor is characteristic of croup, which typically affects the subglottic area of the larynx.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound that occurs during inhalation. It is commonly associated with conditions that cause narrowing of the upper airway above the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Expiratory stridor is a wheezing sound heard during exhalation and is less common. It suggests a problem lower in the respiratory tract, such as the bronchioles or smaller bronchi.

 

Option D. No stridor would mean that there is no abnormal airway sound, which would not be applicable in the context of a discussion about croup, which typically presents with stridor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup typically presents with biphasic stridor, which occurs during both inspiration and expiration, reflecting the subglottic airway narrowing characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: On Head impulse test, for a Left vestibular neuritis patient, Saccade will be in which direction? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right on left head rotation

 

In patients with left vestibular neuritis, the vestibular function on the left side is hypoactive, meaning it functions below normal levels. The head impulse test evaluates the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which helps maintain stable vision during head movements. When the head is moved to the left, the left vestibular system (which is hypoactive in this condition) should excite and the right side should inhibit. However, due to the hypoactivity on the left side, the expected response is delayed or diminished, causing the eyes to initially drift towards the hypoactive side (left) followed by corrective saccadic movements to the right. Therefore, saccades will be observed to the right during left head rotation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left on left head rotation: This is incorrect because in a left vestibular neuritis patient, the left vestibular system is hypoactive. Corrective saccades occur towards the opposite direction (right) when the hypoactive side (left) is stimulated.

 

Option B. Left on right head rotation: Incorrect because during right head rotation, the right vestibular system (which is unaffected) will function normally, leading to appropriate eye movement towards the right without corrective saccades.

 

Option D. Right on right head rotation: Incorrect because the right vestibular system is unaffected. Hence, the eyes will move correctly without saccades during right head rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In left vestibular neuritis, head impulse tests reveal saccades towards the right when the head is rotated to the left due to the hypoactive left vestibular system.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with stage 2 supraglottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice but good airway and swallowing function. Recent 70-pack year smoking history. The patient has undergone following procedure in the ICU shown in the image. Which is the procedure being done in this patient?(Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B). Percutaneous tracheostomy

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows percutaneous tracheostomy which is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: conservative surgery performed in supraglottic cancer to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: While visible in image, this is supportive care, not definitive cancer treatment.

 

Option D. Total laryngectomy: Too radical for stage 2 supraglottic cancer with good function; would result in permanent stoma and loss of natural speech.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand:

  1. Surgical options for laryngeal cancer based on stage
  2. Principles of organ preservation surgery
  3. Role of temporary vs permanent tracheostomy
  4. Post-operative airway management
  5. Importance of functional status in surgical decision-making

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the ER with a two-day history of worsening ear pain and drainage. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing down and out as shown below. The most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Mastoiditis

 

The patient's presentation of worsening ear pain, drainage, and redness behind the ear, along with a prominent right pinna pointing down and out, is indicative of a complication of acute otitis media, specifically acute mastoiditis. Acute mastoiditis is characterized by inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells, often resulting in a post-auricular abscess, as seen in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Otitis externa, or external ear canal infection, typically presents with pain, discharge, and sometimes swelling of the ear canal, but does not usually cause post-auricular redness or a displaced pinna.

 

Option B. Otitis media with effusion: Otitis media with effusion involves the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It does not present with post-auricular redness or abscess.

 

Option D. Coalescent Mastoiditis: Coalescent mastoiditis is a more advanced stage of mastoiditis where the bony septa between mastoid air cells break down, forming a common cavity. This diagnosis could be considered if the condition had been present for a longer duration. However, the acute presentation described fits acute mastoiditis more accurately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media, can present with post-auricular redness, abscess, and displacement of the pinna, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Which is the best stain for biopsy during laryngoscopy for vocal cord examination? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravital

 

The best stain for biopsy during laryngoscopy for vocal cord examination is Toluidine blue, which is a type of supravital stain.

 

Supravital staining allows for the observation of living cells and is particularly useful in this context because it can be used non-invasively during laryngoscopy. Toluidine blue has a high affinity for DNA and RNA, making it effective in highlighting areas with high cellular activity, such as cancerous growths. This stain is particularly useful for detecting early cancerous changes in the vocal cords, as it is absorbed more by cells with high nucleic acid content, indicating a proliferative or carcinomatous state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Silver nitrate: This is primarily used as a cauterizing agent and does not serve as a stain for examining vocal cord tissue in a biopsy. It is not suitable for detecting cellular abnormalities.

 

Option C. H&E (Hematoxylin and Eosin): While commonly used in pathology to stain tissue sections, H&E is not a supravital stain and requires invasive tissue preparation, which is not practical during laryngoscopy.

 

Option D. Congo red: This stain is used for detecting amyloid deposits and is not relevant to vocal cord examination for cancerous growths. It does not have the specificity required for identifying DNA and RNA activity in living cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue, a supravital stain, is the best stain for non-invasive detection of cancerous growths during laryngoscopy of the vocal cords due to its high uptake by cells with active DNA and RNA synthesis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with conductive hearing loss. CT temporal bone shows an isolated erosion of which ossicle shown in the image? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malleus

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows the incus, but the question focuses on ossicular erosion patterns. In chronic otitis media, the lenticular process of the incus is most commonly eroded due to its tenuous blood supply. However, when there is isolated erosion of a single ossicle (without involvement of the incus), it typically affects the malleus head due to cholesteatoma in the epitympanum/attic region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Incus: While incus is the most commonly eroded ossicle overall, isolated erosion of incus without involvement of other ossicles is rare due to its anatomical position and pattern of disease spread in chronic otitis media.

 

Option C. Stapes: Isolated stapes erosion is extremely rare. When stapes is involved, it's usually in conjunction with incus erosion due to the contiguous spread of disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the patterns of ossicular erosion in chronic otitis media and cholesteatoma, with emphasis on:

  1. The blood supply of ossicles
  2. The pattern of disease spread in the middle ear
  3. Clinical correlation with types of hearing loss
  4. Importance of imaging in determining extent of disease

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

The Arnold stick test is not a recognized method for assessing olfaction. The name does not correspond with standard or commonly used olfactory tests, which typically involve the identification or differentiation of specific odors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smell Diskettes: These are used in screening tests for olfaction, where reusable diskettes are impregnated with different odorants. Participants are asked to identify scents from a list, often aided by illustrative questionnaires.

Option C. UPSIT: The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test is a widely recognized and comprehensive olfactory test. It is self-administered and involves scratching odor-impregnated booklets to release smells, which the test-taker must then identify.

Option D. CC-SIT: The Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test, a shorter form of the UPSIT, consists of 12 items and is designed for quick administration, making it practical for use in diverse populations and clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests used for olfaction are as follows:

 

  1. Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  2. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  3. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT), is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  4. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

  • Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance.
  • Electron microscopy -  can detect structural and functional abnormalities of cilia but do not detect any other abnormalities interfering with nasal mucociliary clearance. It is used to visualize the detailed architecture of cilia, which can help identify defects in ciliary structure responsible for impaired mucociliary transport, but it does not measure the actual transport or clearance function.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharin Test: This is a straightforward clinical test where a small amount of saccharin is placed on the nasal mucosa, and the time it takes for the subject to taste the sweetness is measured. This time reflects the mucociliary clearance rate.

 

Option C. Charcoal Powder Method: Involves placing a small amount of charcoal powder in the nose and timing how long it takes for it to appear in the pharynx, similarly assessing the clearance capability of the mucociliary apparatus.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: This nuclear medicine test uses a small amount of radioactive material to track and record mucociliary transport and clearance, providing both functional and anatomical information about the nasal and sinus mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Test for mucociliary clearance is:
    • Saccharin with or without color test in vivo -   Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
    • Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
    • Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
    • Nasal nitric oxide -  Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
    • Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
    • Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
    • The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: A patient with Reinke’s edema will have which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dysphonia

 

  • Dysphonia is the hallmark symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • The swelling in the vocal cords alters their vibration, leading to changes in voice quality, pitch, and loudness.
  • Patients often present with a deep, husky voice, and in severe cases, speech may become effortful.

 

Reinke’s Edema is polypoid degeneration of vocal cords. It is bilateral symmetrical swelling of the whole of membranous part of the vocal cords. This is due to oedema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords.
