Etiology – Chronic irritation of vocal cords due to misuse of voice, heavy smoking, chronic sinusitis and laryngopharyngeal reflex.

 

Clinical features – Hoarseness, Dysphonia, patient uses false cords for voice production and this gives him a low-pitched and rough voice.

 

On indirect laryngoscopy, vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

 

Treatment - Decortication of the vocal cords, Voice rest and Speech therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dysphagia to Solids and Option C. Dysphagia to Liquids:

 

These symptoms relate to difficulty swallowing, which is not typically associated with Reinke’s edema unless there is significant involvement of adjacent structures affecting the swallowing mechanism, which is rare.

 

Option D. Diplophonia:

 

  • Diplophonia (the perception of two simultaneous pitches) can occur in conditions affecting vocal cord vibration but is not a classic feature of Reinke’s edema.
  • It may be observed in some cases of vocal cord lesions, such as polyps or cysts, but it is not a primary symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • Usually diplophonia is seen in unilateral vocal cord pathologies. The affected cord vibrates at a different frequency when compared with the normal cord which vibrates at its regular frequency. This is because vibrational characteristics of affected cord gets changed due to structural changes caused by the lesion. Hence 2 cords, vibrating at 2 different frequencies, will produce 2 different sounds. This is called as diplophonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke's edema primarily affects the vocal cords leading to characteristic symptoms related to voice changes where the patient may experience pain due to movement of swollen vocal cords. Heavy vocal cords require more effort by the vocal muscles to move them. Hence this extra effort of muscles causes pain and early vocal fatigue to the patient. Management involves addressing the underlying causes, surgical intervention, and supportive therapies like voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with hoarseness of voice with a history of significant weight loss. On laryngoscopy, ulceroproliferative growth involving the left vocal fold is seen, as shown below. The vocal cord is fixed. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

 

Explanation:  


The clinical presentation (hoarseness of voice, weight loss) and the laryngoscopic findings (ulceroproliferative growth with fixed vocal cord) suggest advanced glottic carcinoma. The fixed vocal cord indicates at least T3 stage, as it suggests tumor infiltration into the paraglottic space or fixation due to deeper invasion. Weight loss in an elderly patient further supports an advanced stage malignancy.

 

This is the preferred treatment for T3 or T4 laryngeal cancers, especially when the vocal cords are fixed, and there is a high likelihood of regional spread. If the patient has significant lymph node involvement or is symptomatic (e.g., weight loss), a neck dissection is warranted along with total laryngectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical Radiotherapy: Radical radiotherapy is usually preferred for early-stage laryngeal cancers (T1 or T2) with mobile vocal cords. It is less effective for advanced stages (T3 or T4) due to higher chances of recurrence.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for advanced laryngeal carcinoma unless the patient is unsuitable for surgery or radiation. It is primarily used for palliative care or in cases with distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Concurrent Chemoradiation: Concurrent chemoradiation is a consideration for organ preservation in advanced laryngeal cancers. However, for patients with a fixed vocal cord and significant weight loss, total laryngectomy provides better local control and survival outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:


For advanced glottic carcinoma with vocal cord fixation (T3/T4) and evidence of regional spread, the best treatment option is Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown on x-ray. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double ring sign

 

The x-ray shows a round object in the esophagus, which is identified as a button battery due to the characteristic appearance known as the "double ring sign." This sign is seen when a button battery is lodged in the esophagus; the object appears to have two distinct concentric rings. The esophagus, which runs vertically in the body, causes the face of the battery or coin to present anteroposteriorly on the x-ray, which means it shows as a full circle when viewed from the front. A coin, unlike a button battery, does not have this double ring appearance. Recognizing the double ring sign is crucial because a button battery lodged in the esophagus is a medical emergency due to the risk of severe tissue damage from the battery's contents.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. String sign: This sign is typically associated with Crohn's disease and represents a narrowing of the bowel lumen, not applicable to foreign bodies in the esophagus.

 

Option C. Steeple sign: This sign is indicative of croup and appears as a tapering of the upper trachea on an x-ray, resembling a church steeple. It does not apply to the appearance of a button battery or coin in the esophagus.

Option D. Thumb sign: This sign is seen in epiglottitis, where the swollen epiglottis resembles a thumb on a lateral neck x-ray. It is unrelated to the presentation of a button battery in the esophagus.

Educational Objective:

 

The double ring sign on an x-ray indicates the presence of a button battery in the esophagus, distinguished by two concentric rings, which is critical to identify promptly due to the potential for severe complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with known Samter's triad presents with severe migraine. After successful aspirin desensitization therapy 6 months ago, he has been on daily aspirin maintenance. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketorolac

 

Explanation: 

 

In a patient who has undergone aspirin desensitization for Samter's triad, the key consideration is maintaining the desensitized state.

 

Key points:

  • After successful aspirin desensitization, patients must continue daily aspirin therapy to maintain the desensitized state
  • Introduction of other COX-1 inhibitors (like ketorolac) can trigger severe reactions even in desensitized patients
  • Non-COX-1 inhibiting pain medications are safe to use

 

The mechanism behind this involves:

  • Aspirin desensitization modifies leukotriene production pathways specifically for aspirin
  • Other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1 can still trigger reactions through independent pathways
  • This is why even desensitized patients must avoid other NSAIDs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetaminophen: Safe to use as it has minimal COX-1 inhibition and is generally well-tolerated in aspirin-sensitive patients.

 

Option C. Sumatriptan: A triptan medication that works through serotonin receptors and is safe for migraine treatment in these patients.

 

Option D. Topiramate: An anticonvulsant used for migraine prophylaxis that doesn't affect COX pathways.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that aspirin desensitization in Samter's triad doesn't confer protection against other NSAIDs, and recognizing safe alternative pain management options in these patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe ear pain and tenderness over the mastoid area following tooth extraction and jaw manipulation. Post-procedure examination shows no middle ear pathology. Which nerve is most likely responsible for the referred pain? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation: 

 

The auriculotemporal nerve (V3) is most likely responsible in this case because:

  • It's a branch of mandibular nerve that provides sensory innervation to TMJ, parotid region, and anterior part of ear
  • Dental procedures and jaw manipulation can irritate this nerve
  • Its anatomical course makes it susceptible to compression or irritation during dental procedures
  • The distribution matches the patient's symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve: While important for referred otalgia, it's primarily involved in pharyngeal pathology rather than dental/TMJ issues.

 

Option B. Greater auricular nerve: Though it supplies the mastoid area, it originates from C2,3 and isn't directly affected by dental procedures.

 

Option D. Auricular branch of vagus nerve: Supplies the concha and antihelix, but isn't typically involved in dental procedure-related pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand:

  1. Pathways of referred ear pain
  2. Nerve distribution in the ear and temporal region
  3. Clinical correlation with dental procedures
  4. Differential diagnosis of otalgia
  5. Anatomical basis of TMJ-related ear symptoms

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JNA

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The typical presentation includes nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Rhinitis: Nasal obstruction but no recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Coagulation Disorder: Bleeding from multiple sites, not specific to nasal obstruction in adolescent males.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal Polyp: Nasal obstruction without recurrent epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.
  • Types of stridor and sites of origin
    • Inspiratory stridor - laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
    • Expiratory stridor - bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
    • Biphasic stridor - laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subglottic - More commonly associated with biphasic stridor due to narrowing at the level just below the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Tracheal - Can cause either biphasic or expiratory stridor depending on the extent and exact location of the obstruction.

 

Option D. Bronchus - Primarily causes expiratory stridor due to obstructions in the lower airways.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 333, 334

choices.text: Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained
Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss
Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery
Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant patient presented with complaints of worsening of hearing since the onset of pregnancy. On PTA the following graph was obtained. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is true? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, being pregnant and experiencing worsening hearing loss, suggests otosclerosis. The provided PTA (Pure Tone Audiogram) shows a significant air-bone gap on the right side, indicating conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Definitely, air travel is contraindicated for patients post-stapedectomy for at least three months. The variations in middle ear pressure during ascent and descent can lead to displacement or dislocation of the prosthetic piston used in the surgery, making this statement true.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained: In otosclerosis, an As type of tympanogram (indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system) is typically obtained, not Ad. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss: A notch at 2000Hz on bone conduction is known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis, not noise-induced hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss typically presents a notch at 4000Hz. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery: Ménière's disease is indeed a contraindication for stapes surgery. The presence of Ménière's disease can lead to complications such as irritation of the saccule during the surgery, causing vertigo and giddiness. Thus, this statement is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Air travel is contraindicated for at least three months post-stapedectomy due to the risk of pressure-induced displacement or dislocation of the surgical prosthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

 

 

Image A shows Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) and it can be used in managing B/L external auditory canal atresia.

 

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
  2. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
  3. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
  4. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  5. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  6. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy piston is used in otosclerosis patients.

 

Option D. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis is used to replace the incudo-stapedial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule which are re-opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.

 

In Modified Young's operation, partial closure of the nostril is done to avoid discomfort.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasomotor rhinitis - Typically managed with medications such as antihistamines and nasal sprays; surgery is not a standard treatment.

 

Option C. Invasive aspergillosis - Treatment involves antifungal medications; surgical debridement may be necessary but does not involve closing the nostrils.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis - Managed with allergy medications, immunotherapy, and avoiding allergens; surgery is not indicated for occluding nostrils.

 

Educational Objective:


Young's operation is a unique surgical technique reserved for severe cases of atrophic rhinitis where other treatments have failed. This procedure helps in restoring the normal function and structure of the nasal mucosa by temporarily occluding the nostrils to allow healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The Jacobson nerve / tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Jacobson nerve = tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal (IX cranial nerve) – supplies middle ear mucosa. Referred otalgia from tonsillitis / pharyngitis / Cancers of base of tongue is due to this nerve common innervation (ear & pharynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater Auricular Nerve: Arises from the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and primarily innervates the skin over the parotid gland and mastoid region, not typically involved in referred ear pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which innervates the anterior auricle and external acoustic meatus, contributing to sensations in these areas but not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Auricular Branch of Vagus Nerve: Also known as Arnold’s nerve, supplies the concha and part of the external auditory canal and could potentially contribute to referred otalgia, but not primarily responsible in cases of tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal cancer

 

Given the age of the patient and the presence of both right-sided serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, the most likely diagnosis is Nasopharyngeal cancer.

 

Nasopharyngeal cancer can present with serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube obstruction by the tumor or swollen lymph nodes in the nasopharyngeal region. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also a common finding due to the spread of the malignancy to the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiofibroma, specifically juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is a benign tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. It can cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds), but is less commonly associated with serous otitis media and is not typically diagnosed in a 50-year-old male.

 

Option C. Adenoid hypertrophy is more common in children and can cause eustachian tube dysfunction leading to serous otitis media; however, it is unlikely to be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy, especially in adults.

 

Option D. Otitis media with effusion, also known as serous otitis media, is the accumulation of fluid within the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can be a result of eustachian tube dysfunction, which could be secondary to a mass effect from a nasopharyngeal tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an adult patient presents with serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal cancer as a possible diagnosis, especially in the context of risk factors such as age over 50 years and a history suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old brought to the emergency department with complaints of mild bloody rhinorrhea. On examination, he was awake and oriented. Drainage has soiled his shirt, and the appearance of which is given below. This is seen in case of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic CSF Rhinorrhea

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with mild bloody rhinorrhea, and the drainage has created a characteristic "halo sign" or "double ring sign" on his shirt. This sign indicates the presence of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) mixed with blood. The halo sign is seen when CSF forms a clear ring around a central bloody spot on absorbent material. This finding is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where trauma causes a breach in the meninges, allowing CSF to leak and mix with nasal secretions or blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea: Spontaneous CSF rhinorrhea typically involves clear CSF leakage without blood. The absence of blood would not produce the halo sign as described.

 

Option C. Meningocele: Meningocele involves herniation of the meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column but does not typically cause nasal CSF leakage mixed with blood. It usually presents as a mass or bulge.

 

Option D. Tumors: Tumors might cause nasal discharge, but the presence of a halo sign specifically points to a CSF leak, which is more characteristic of traumatic causes rather than tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The halo sign or double ring sign on absorbent material is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where CSF leaks and mixes with blood, creating a central red spot surrounded by a clear or yellowish ring.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

 

The image shows a tracheostomy tube, which is not used for upper airway examination.

 

Tracheostomy:

 

  • It is a procedure where alternative airway is established when normal airway is compromised.
  • An opening is made on the anterior wall of trachea and a tube is inserted, through which air exchange occurs between lungs and outside.
  • It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
  • Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
  • High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.
  • In emergency tracheostomy, vertical incision is taken but in elective cases, horizontal incision is taken.
  • It is generally a temporary procedure till the pathology in the upper bypassed airway clears.
  • In some cases, like cancer larynx where laryngectomy was done, permanent tracheostomy is done.
  • Removal of tracheostomy tube is called decannulation.
  • Different types of tracheostomy tubes – PVC, Metallic (Chevalier-Jackson), etc.
  • Complications of tracheostomy → surgical emphysema, hemorrhage, Apnea due to CO2 washout, Pneumothorax, Tube displacement, Tube blockage, Tracheomalacia, Subglottic stenosis

 

Other Options:

 

Primary Uses of a Tracheostomy Tube Include:

 

Option A. Airway Toileting: Facilitates the removal of secretions from the airways.

 

Option C. Acute Nasopharyngeal Obstruction: Provides an airway bypass in cases of blockage in the upper airway.

 

Option D. Prolonged Mechanical Ventilation: Offers a secure, stable method for long-term ventilation support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.
